title: Circumference and Area of Circles
description: Discover the number pi and learn to calculate the circumference and area of circles.
objectives: Understand the relationship between diameter, radius, and pi
Calculate the circumference of a circle using $C = 2\pi r$ or $C = \pi d$
Calculate the area of a circle using $A = \pi r^2$

sections.title: The Magic of Circles
sections.content:
Circles are everywhere — wheels, clocks, pizzas, coins. But unlike rectangles or triangles, circles have curved edges, so we need a special number to help us measure them. That number is **pi** ($\pi$), one of the most famous numbers in mathematics.

$\pi \approx 3.14159...$ It goes on forever without repeating!

sections.title: Parts of a Circle
sections.content:
Before we calculate, let's name the key parts:

- **Centre**: The middle point of the circle
- **Radius** ($r$): The distance from the centre to any point on the circle
- **Diameter** ($d$): The distance across the circle through the centre. $d = 2r$
- **Circumference** ($C$): The distance around the circle (its perimeter)

The amazing fact about $\pi$: for **every** circle, the circumference divided by the diameter equals $\pi$.

$$\frac{C}{d} = \pi$$

sections.title: Circumference
sections.content:
The **circumference** (distance around the circle) can be found using either formula:

$$C = \pi d \quad \text{or} \quad C = 2\pi r$$

These are the same formula since $d = 2r$.

Example: A circle has a radius of $7\text{ cm}$.
$$C = 2\pi r = 2 \times \pi \times 7 = 14\pi \approx 43.98\text{ cm}$$

When the question says 'give your answer in terms of $\pi$', write $14\pi\text{ cm}$.
When it says 'round to one decimal place', calculate $14 \times 3.14159... \approx 44.0\text{ cm}$.

sections.title: Area of a Circle
sections.content:
The **area** of a circle is:

$$A = \pi r^2$$

Remember: $r^2$ means $r \times r$, NOT $2 \times r$!

Example: A circle has a radius of $5\text{ m}$.
$$A = \pi \times 5^2 = \pi \times 25 = 25\pi \approx 78.5\text{ m}^2$$

If you're given the **diameter**, halve it first to get the radius:
- Diameter $= 12\text{ cm}$ means radius $= 6\text{ cm}$
- $A = \pi \times 6^2 = 36\pi \approx 113.1\text{ cm}^2$

sections.title: Common Mistakes to Avoid
sections.content:
Watch out for these traps:

1. **Using diameter instead of radius** in the area formula. $A = \pi r^2$, NOT $\pi d^2$!
2. **Squaring before multiplying by $\pi$**. Correct: $\pi \times r^2 = \pi \times r \times r$
3. **Confusing $2r$ with $r^2$**. Doubling and squaring are very different: $2 \times 5 = 10$ but $5^2 = 25$
4. **Forgetting units**: Circumference uses linear units (cm, m) but area uses square units ($\text{cm}^2$, $\text{m}^2$)

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- $\pi \approx 3.14159$ is the ratio of circumference to diameter for every circle
- Circumference: $C = 2\pi r$ or $C = \pi d$
- Area: $A = \pi r^2$
- Always check whether you've been given the radius or the diameter

workedExamples.title: Finding Both Circumference and Area
workedExamples.problem: A circular garden has a diameter of $10\text{ m}$. Find its circumference and area. Give answers to one decimal place.
workedExamples.explanation: We halved the diameter to get the radius, then applied both formulas. Note the different units: metres for circumference, square metres for area.

workedExamples.title: Working Backwards from Circumference
workedExamples.problem: A circular track has a circumference of $400\text{ m}$. What is the radius of the track? Give your answer to the nearest whole number.
workedExamples.explanation: We rearranged the circumference formula to find $r$ by dividing both sides by $2\pi$.

title: Volume of Cylinders and Scale Drawings
description: Calculate the volume of cylinders and work with scale drawings and scale factors.
objectives: Calculate the volume of a cylinder using $V = \pi r^2 h$
Convert between real-life dimensions and scale dimensions

sections.title: Cylinders and Scaled-Down Worlds
sections.content:
A cylinder is one of the most common 3D shapes — think of cans, pipes, and water tanks. In this lesson, you'll learn how to calculate how much a cylinder can hold.

We'll also explore **scale drawings**, which are used in maps, floor plans, and architecture to represent real-world objects at a reduced (or enlarged) size.

sections.title: Volume of a Cylinder
sections.content:
A **cylinder** is like a stack of circles. Its volume is the area of the circular base multiplied by the height:

$$V = \pi r^2 h$$

where $r$ = radius of the base and $h$ = height of the cylinder.

Example: A cylinder has radius $4\text{ cm}$ and height $10\text{ cm}$:
$$V = \pi \times 4^2 \times 10 = \pi \times 16 \times 10 = 160\pi \approx 502.7\text{ cm}^3$$

If the cylinder holds liquid, $1\text{ cm}^3 = 1\text{ mL}$, so this cylinder holds about $503\text{ mL}$.

sections.title: Real-World Cylinder Problem
sections.content: A water tank is a cylinder with diameter $2\text{ m}$ and height $3\text{ m}$. How many litres of water can it hold? ($1\text{ m}^3 = 1{,}000\text{ L}$)

sections.title: Scale Drawings
sections.content:
A **scale drawing** is a proportional representation of a real object. The **scale** tells you the ratio between the drawing and reality.

A scale of $1 : 100$ means $1\text{ cm}$ on the drawing represents $100\text{ cm}$ ($1\text{ m}$) in real life.

**Drawing to Real Life:** Multiply the drawing measurement by the scale factor.
- Drawing length $= 5\text{ cm}$, Scale $= 1 : 200$
- Real length $= 5 \times 200 = 1{,}000\text{ cm} = 10\text{ m}$

**Real Life to Drawing:** Divide the real measurement by the scale factor.
- Real length $= 15\text{ m} = 1{,}500\text{ cm}$, Scale $= 1 : 500$
- Drawing length $= 1{,}500 \div 500 = 3\text{ cm}$

sections.title: Scale Factor
sections.content:
The **scale factor** describes how many times larger (or smaller) the real object is compared to the drawing.

For a scale of $1 : n$:
- Multiply drawing lengths by $n$ to get real lengths
- Divide real lengths by $n$ to get drawing lengths

Important: Scale applies to **lengths only**. For areas, you must square the scale factor. For volumes, you must cube it.
- If lengths are scaled by $k$, areas are scaled by $k^2$
- If lengths are scaled by $k$, volumes are scaled by $k^3$

sections.title: What We Learned
sections.content:
- Volume of a cylinder: $V = \pi r^2 h$
- $1\text{ cm}^3 = 1\text{ mL}$ and $1\text{ m}^3 = 1{,}000\text{ L}$
- Scale drawings use a ratio to represent real-world measurements
- Multiply drawing measurements by the scale factor to find real-life dimensions
- Scale affects lengths directly, but areas and volumes need squared/cubed scale factors

workedExamples.title: Cylinder Volume
workedExamples.problem: A tin can has a radius of $3.5\text{ cm}$ and a height of $12\text{ cm}$. Find its volume to the nearest whole number.
workedExamples.explanation: We squared the radius ($3.5^2 = 12.25$), multiplied by the height, then by $\pi$.

workedExamples.title: Scale Drawing Problem
workedExamples.problem: On a map with scale $1 : 50{,}000$, two towns are $8\text{ cm}$ apart. What is the real distance in kilometres?
workedExamples.explanation: We multiplied the map distance by the scale factor and then converted centimetres to kilometres.
